subcategories.name: Medical & Welfare
subcategories.description: Medical examinations, welfare provisions, and service health matters.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 130101, what is the general policy regarding medical treatment of public officers
options: Officers are responsible for their own treatment.
Government provides medical attention in approved hospitals.
Treatment is only provided for senior officers.
Only emergency cases are covered.
questions.explanation: PSR 130101 provides that Government shall ensure medical attention to officers and their families in approved facilities.

questions.question: Which category of officers is eligible for medical treatment at Government expense under **PSR** 2021
options: All public officers and their dependants as defined in PSR 130102.
Procedurally, only directors and permanent secretaries within applicable policy conditions.
In practice, contract staff only in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, political appointees under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 130102 defines dependants and states that all public officers and their recognized dependants are entitled to medical treatment at Government expense.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 130104, who authorizes medical treatment outside Nigeria
options: Permanent Secretary.
Minister of Health.
President on the advice of a Medical Board.
Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130104 stipulates that the President may approve treatment abroad based on the recommendation of a Medical Board.

questions.question: **PSR** 130106 provides that medical examination before appointment is:
options: Optional for senior officers.
Compulsory for all categories of appointments.
Only for permanent appointments.
Required only for officers above GL.10.
questions.explanation: PSR 130106 mandates medical examination for all new entrants before assumption of duty to ensure fitness.

questions.question: When an officer is sick for more than 21 consecutive days, **PSR** 130107 requires that
options: His salary be suspended.
He undergo medical board assessment.
He be retired automatically.
He provide self-medical report.
questions.explanation: PSR 130107 requires that any officer absent for more than 21 days due to illness must be examined by a Medical Board.

questions.question: Who certifies sick leave under **PSR** 130108
options: Permanent Secretary.
Recognized Government or approved medical officer.
Private clinic of the officerâ€™s choice.
Director of Administration.
questions.explanation: PSR 130108 states that sick leave must be supported by a certificate from a recognized Government medical officer.

questions.question: What is the maximum period of sick leave with full pay in **PSR** 130109
options: 45 days.
90 days.
180 days.
270 days.
questions.explanation: PSR 130109 provides that officers may be granted up to 180 days of sick leave with full pay upon certification by a Medical Board.

questions.question: **PSR** 130110 provides that if an officer is not fit after maximum sick leave, the next step is:
options: Termination.
Extension without pay or retirement on medical grounds.
Suspension.
Posting to a lighter schedule.
questions.explanation: PSR 130110 requires that if the officer is still unfit after maximum sick leave, the case shall be referred to the Medical Board for retirement or extension without pay.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 130111, what constitutes injury on duty
options: Any injury sustained during leisure time.
Injury sustained while performing official duties or as a direct consequence of it.
Injury at home during leave.
Injury during private business.
questions.explanation: PSR 130111 defines injury on duty as any injury occurring in the course of or arising directly from official duty.

questions.question: Compensation for injury or death in service is governed under which **PSR** rule
questions.explanation: PSR 130112 outlines procedures for compensation and benefits for injury, disability, or death in the line of duty.

questions.question: Who is responsible for verifying medical bills submitted for refund
options: Permanent Secretary.
Medical Board or designated Government doctor.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130105(b) requires medical bills to be verified by a Medical Board or designated Government doctor before reimbursement.

questions.question: What is the purpose of **PSR** 130113 on medical confidentiality
options: To ensure privacy of officers' medical information.
To allow open disclosure of illness.
To share records with colleagues.
To publish medical data for transparency.
questions.explanation: PSR 130113 ensures that medical information about officers remains confidential and released only with authorization.

questions.question: **PSR** 130115 provides that officers posted to remote or hazardous areas may receive:
options: Leave allowance.
Hardship or hazard allowance.
Training benefit.
Overtime payment.
questions.explanation: PSR 130115 allows payment of hardship or hazard allowance to officers serving in difficult or high-risk areas.

questions.question: Medical examination for promotion or transfer is guided by which **PSR** provision
questions.explanation: PSR 130114 provides for medical examination in connection with promotion, transfer, or retirement as necessary.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule provides for reimbursement of expenses incurred on emergency treatment
questions.explanation: PSR 130105 allows refund for approved emergency medical treatment when immediate attention is necessary.

questions.question: **PSR** 130107 states that where illness continues beyond 12 months, the officer shall:
options: Be deemed permanently unfit for service.
Be granted additional paid leave.
Return to duty compulsorily.
Be posted to light duty.
questions.explanation: PSR 130107(c) provides that illness exceeding 12 months indicates permanent unfitness for service and triggers medical retirement.

questions.question: The purpose of **PSR** 130111â€“130113 is to ensure officers injured in service receive:
options: Disciplinary review.
Medical care and financial compensation.
Special promotion.
Foreign training.
questions.explanation: PSR 130111â€“130113 provide for medical care, compensation, or pension benefits to officers injured in the course of duty.

questions.question: Officers may be required to undergo periodic medical examination under **PSR**:
questions.explanation: PSR 130114 empowers the Government to request periodic medical examinations to confirm officersâ€™ continued fitness for duty.

questions.question: **PSR** 130112 ensures that dependants of an officer who dies in service are entitled to:
options: Compassionate leave.
Free housing.
Death benefits and compensation.
Training opportunities.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(b) guarantees payment of compensation and death benefits to dependants of officers who die in service.

questions.question: What body determines the amount of compensation payable under **PSR** 130112
options: Medical Board.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Permanent Secretary.
Ministry of Labour and Employment.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(c) provides that the Medical Board determines compensation based on degree of injury or disability.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 130101, what must officers do when reporting for medical treatment
options: Present their staff ID and medical registration card.
Provide a guarantor.
Pay partial bills.
Seek written approval first.
questions.explanation: PSR 130101(b) requires officers to present staff identification and medical registration card for treatment at government-approved hospitals.

questions.question: Who convenes the Medical Board for assessing prolonged illness
options: Permanent Secretary.
Head of Civil Service.
Director of Administration.
Ministry of Health.
questions.explanation: PSR 130107(b) provides that the Permanent Secretary convenes the Medical Board when an officerâ€™s illness exceeds 21 days.

questions.question: **PSR** 130115 allows Government to pay hazard allowance to officers working in:
options: Comfortable urban centres.
Diplomatic missions only.
Areas involving danger or health risk.
Headquarters postings.
questions.explanation: PSR 130115 defines hazard allowance as payable to officers working in dangerous or high-risk environments.

questions.question: Which **PSR** provision covers treatment of dependants of officers
questions.explanation: PSR 130102 clearly states that dependants of public officers are entitled to medical treatment at Government expense.

questions.question: What **PSR** rule governs the refund of medical expenses incurred in emergencies
questions.explanation: PSR 130105 authorizes refund of medical expenses where immediate treatment was necessary and prior approval could not be obtained.

questions.question: **PSR** 130110 empowers a Medical Board to recommend which of the following actions
options: Operationally, disciplinary suspension under normal controls.
Extension of leave without pay or retirement on medical grounds.
In practice, salary increase in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, transfer to another department under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 130110 allows a Medical Board to recommend extension of sick leave without pay or medical retirement if unfitness persists.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 130113, medical records of officers should be handled with:
options: Confidentiality.
Administrative review.
Supervisory oversight.
Public disclosure.
questions.explanation: PSR 130113 requires confidentiality of officers' medical records, ensuring privacy except when disclosure is authorized.

questions.question: **PSR** 130107 stipulates that a Medical Board must be convened after illness lasts more than:
options: 14 consecutive days.
21 consecutive days.
30 consecutive days.
60 consecutive days.
questions.explanation: PSR 130107(a) mandates that a Medical Board be convened when illness exceeds 21 consecutive days.

questions.question: What **PSR** provision authorizes periodic health check-ups for serving officers
questions.explanation: PSR 130114 empowers the Government to arrange periodic medical examinations for officers to assess ongoing fitness for duty.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule allows the Government to provide insurance coverage for public officers
questions.explanation: PSR 130116 provides that Government may arrange group life insurance policies to cover officers against death or permanent disability.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 130112, compensation claims must be supported by:
options: A written request from the officer.
Certified report by a Medical Board.
Recommendation from Head of Service.
Approval from Ministry of Labour.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(b) requires that all compensation claims be supported by certified Medical Board reports establishing injury or death in service.

questions.question: Officers who refuse medical examination when directed may face:
options: Medical suspension.
Disciplinary action for insubordination.
Automatic retirement.
Salary deduction.
questions.explanation: PSR 130114(b) provides that refusal to undergo mandatory medical examination constitutes misconduct under PSR 100201.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 130105, officers who seek medical attention in emergencies must:
options: Inform their Head of Department as soon as possible.
Pay bills in advance.
Report only after recovery.
Submit claims to FCSC directly.
questions.explanation: PSR 130105(b) requires officers to notify their Head of Department promptly after emergency treatment for claim processing.

questions.question: When an officer dies as a result of injury sustained on duty, compensation is payable to
options: The officerâ€™s next of kin or dependants.
The Ministryâ€™s welfare fund.
His departmentâ€™s account.
The Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(a) states that compensation shall be paid to the deceased officerâ€™s next of kin or dependants.

questions.question: Which **PSR** provision restricts medical treatment abroad unless facilities are unavailable locally
questions.explanation: PSR 130104 restricts treatment abroad to cases certified by a Medical Board as unmanageable within Nigeria.

questions.question: Who may authorize emergency medical expenditure refund in Ministries
options: Permanent Secretary.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Ministry of Health.
Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130105(c) empowers the Accounting Officer (Permanent Secretary) to approve verified emergency medical refunds.

questions.question: **PSR** 130112(b) provides that compensation for permanent disability shall depend on:
options: Length of service.
Degree of disability assessed by Medical Board.
Officerâ€™s salary grade.
Recommendation from the Ministry of Finance.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(b) states that the amount of compensation depends on the degree of disability certified by a Medical Board.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 130115, hazard allowance may be withdrawn when:
options: The officer retires.
The hazardous condition ceases to exist.
The officer goes on leave.
After three years of service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130115(b) states that hazard allowance ceases once the officer is no longer exposed to hazardous conditions.

questions.question: What document must be completed for an officer to claim compensation under **PSR** 130112
options: Medical Board report form.
Leave form.
Salary claim form.
Official memorandum.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(a) requires completion of a Medical Board report form confirming injury or death before compensation can be processed.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 130111, when does injury qualify as compensable
options: When sustained during official duty or as its direct consequence.
Procedurally, when it occurs at home within applicable policy conditions.
In practice, if the officer is off duty in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, if caused by negligence under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 130111 provides that injury qualifies for compensation only when sustained during or due to official duty.

questions.question: What **PSR** provision provides for medical treatment of dependants abroad in exceptional cases
questions.explanation: PSR 130104(c) allows dependants' treatment abroad only when the President approves on medical advice.

questions.question: **PSR** 130107(a) requires medical review of prolonged illness after how many months
options: 3 months.
6 months.
9 months.
12 months.
questions.explanation: PSR 130107(a) directs review of prolonged illness after six months for assessment by the Medical Board.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule ensures confidentiality of officers' medical conditions
questions.explanation: PSR 130113 safeguards confidentiality of all medical records and reports of public officers.

options: Federal Civil Service Commission.
Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.
Medical Director.
Ministry of Labour.
questions.explanation: PSR 130115(b) assigns responsibility for health, safety, and welfare of officers to the Accounting Officer of each Ministry.

questions.question: When can an officer on sick leave be recalled to duty
options: When the officer requests it.
After 60 days of leave.
Only when a Medical Board certifies fitness to resume.
Upon directive from supervisor.
questions.explanation: PSR 130109(c) states that officers can resume duty only after being certified fit by a Government medical officer.

questions.question: Who approves retirement on medical grounds under **PSR** 130110
options: Medical Board.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Permanent Secretary.
Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 130110 provides that the Federal Civil Service Commission approves medical retirement upon recommendation of a Medical Board.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 130112, compensation is not payable if injury results from:
options: Accident at workplace.
Officerâ€™s own negligence or misconduct.
Official travel.
Field assignment.
questions.explanation: PSR 130112(c) disallows compensation where injury or death results from the officerâ€™s negligence or misconduct.

Procedurally, salary advance within applicable policy conditions.
In practice, overtime payment in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, training reimbursement under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 130116 ensures insurance benefits cover death, injury, or permanent disability of officers during service.

options: When the officer prefers foreign hospitals.
Only when facilities for adequate treatment are unavailable in Nigeria.
When the officer can afford it.
Whenever requested by a superior officer.
questions.explanation: PSR 130104(a) limits treatment abroad to cases certified as untreatable in Nigeria by a Medical Board.

Private sector medical reliance.

subcategories.name: Training, Performance & Career Development
subcategories.description: Training obligations, performance, and progression pathways.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070101, the purpose of training in the Public Service is to:
options: Improve staff salaries.
Enhance efficiency and effectiveness in service delivery.
Reduce the workforce.
Reward loyalty to superiors.
questions.explanation: PSR 070101 provides that the purpose of training is to develop officersâ€™ efficiency, effectiveness, and performance in public service delivery.

questions.question: **PSR** 070102 emphasizes that training should be based on:
options: Political influence.
Organizational needs and manpower planning.
Officerâ€™s personal choice.
Availability of foreign sponsorship.
questions.explanation: PSR 070102 states that all training must be guided by manpower requirements and organizational development plans.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070104, the Head of Service is responsible for:
options: Recruiting training consultants.
Issuing training circulars and guidelines for the Service.
Supervising all ministries directly.
Approving staff transfers.
questions.explanation: PSR 070104 designates the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation to issue policy guidelines and coordinate training across MDAs.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 070105, every Ministry, Department, or Agency must have a:
options: Training and Staff Development Committee.
Public Relations Unit.
Budget Monitoring Team.
Research Department.
questions.explanation: PSR 070105 mandates that every MDA establish a Training and Staff Development Committee to oversee training programs.

questions.question: **PSR** 070107 requires officers to undergo training relevant to:
options: Their immediate duties and future responsibilities.
Political appointments.
Private business interest.
Any available course.
questions.explanation: PSR 070107 emphasizes that officers should undertake training related to their present and anticipated job roles.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 050102, performance appraisal should be based on:
options: Length of service.
Seniority and loyalty.
Measured results, outputs, and behavioural competencies.
Colleague recommendations.
questions.explanation: PSR 050102 provides that performance is to be assessed using objective criteriaâ€”results, outputs, and behaviour.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 070106, training nominations must be approved by:
options: The Director of Human Resources.
Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Head of Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 070106 stipulates that training nominations are subject to approval by the Accounting Officer of the MDA.

questions.question: **PSR** 050105 introduces which key performance evaluation tool
options: Annual Confidential Report (ACR).
Performance Management System (PMS).
Staff Rating Schedule.
Competency Register.
questions.explanation: PSR 050105 establishes the Performance Management System (PMS) as the new evaluation mechanism replacing the ACR.

questions.question: **PSR** 070108 provides that training abroad shall only be approved when:
options: Equivalent training is unavailable in Nigeria.
The officer has foreign sponsors.
Requested by the officer.
Funds are donated by private firms.
questions.explanation: PSR 070108 restricts foreign training approvals to cases where equivalent local training is unavailable.

questions.question: Which **PSR** provision makes attendance of mandatory promotion examination compulsory
questions.explanation: PSR 020706 provides that passing the prescribed promotion or confirmation examination is compulsory for advancement in the Service.

questions.question: **PSR** 070111 states that training evaluation must be conducted to:
options: Reward participants.
Measure the impact on performance and service delivery.
Determine staff loyalty.
Justify budget expenditure only.
questions.explanation: PSR 070111 requires training impact evaluation to ensure improved performance and organizational outcomes.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule provides that training is a continuous process throughout an officerâ€™s career
questions.explanation: PSR 070103 emphasizes that training and development are continuous processes aimed at improving officersâ€™ competence throughout their career.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 050106, feedback from performance appraisal should be:
options: Confidential and not shared.
Used to support staff development and training plans.
Used only for disciplinary action.
Filed and ignored.
questions.explanation: PSR 050106 provides that performance appraisal results should guide staff development and training programs.

questions.question: **PSR** 070112 requires Ministries to allocate at least what percentage of their personnel budget to training
questions.explanation: PSR 070112 recommends that not less than 5% of each MDAâ€™s personnel cost be earmarked annually for staff training.

questions.question: **PSR** 050103 provides that every officer must have:
options: A defined career path and performance plan.
A private mentor.
Access to overtime allowance.
Annual travel opportunities.
questions.explanation: PSR 050103 establishes that each officer must have a defined performance plan aligned to career and organizational goals.

questions.question: **PSR** 070107(a) emphasizes that officers shall not be nominated for training unless:
options: They have served for 10 years.
They have demonstrated potential for effective utilization of the training.
They have pending disciplinary cases.
The training is free.
questions.explanation: PSR 070107(a) provides that officers must demonstrate potential to apply training outcomes effectively before nomination.

questions.question: **PSR** 050104 directs that performance appraisals should be conducted:
options: Quarterly.
Bi-annually.
Annually or as prescribed.
Every three years.
questions.explanation: PSR 050104 mandates annual performance appraisals to monitor progress and guide decisions on promotions or training.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070110, training institutions for the public service must be:
options: Privately owned.
Accredited and recognized by the Government.
Located in state capitals only.
Under donor agencies.
questions.explanation: PSR 070110 states that only accredited and Government-approved institutions shall conduct public service training.

questions.question: Performance improvement plans under **PSR** 050107 are used to:
options: Reward low-performing staff.
Develop officers whose performance falls below expectations.
Replace supervisors.
Grant automatic promotions.
questions.explanation: PSR 050107 introduces performance improvement plans to support officers who fail to meet expected targets.

questions.question: **PSR** 070109 stipulates that officers who attend training without approval shall:
options: Be commended for initiative.
Receive no recognition or reimbursement.
Be promoted faster.
Get half salary during training.
questions.explanation: PSR 070109 states that self-sponsored or unapproved training shall not earn official recognition or refund.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule requires ministries to maintain training records for all officers
questions.explanation: PSR 070113 mandates the maintenance of a comprehensive training database for all officers within each MDA.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050102, key performance indicators (KPIs) should measure:
options: Staff attendance.
Outputs, behaviour, and results achieved.
Years of service.
Team popularity.
questions.explanation: PSR 050102 states that KPIs must reflect measurable outputs and behavioural performance indicators.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070101(b), training is a joint responsibility between:
options: The officer and their supervisor.
The Federal Civil Service Commission and the Ministry of Finance.
The Government and the individual officer.
Private consultants.
questions.explanation: PSR 070101(b) emphasizes that both Government and officers share responsibility for career-long training and development.

questions.question: **PSR** 050101 provides that performance management is designed to:
options: Replace discipline procedures.
Align individual performance with organizational goals.
Determine annual leave schedules.
Calculate pension benefits.
questions.explanation: PSR 050101 introduces performance management to align individual contributions with organizational objectives.

questions.question: **PSR** 070114 provides that officers who abscond from approved training may face:
options: A fine only.
Disciplinary action including refund of expenses.
Reassignment to another department.
Suspension of promotion eligibility.
questions.explanation: PSR 070114 stipulates disciplinary action and refund of costs for officers who abandon approved training programs.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070115, officers who successfully complete training shall:
options: Be entitled to automatic promotion.
Be required to submit a report on the training to their MDA.
Take another training immediately.
Receive cash reward.
questions.explanation: PSR 070115 mandates officers to submit post-training reports to their MDA, assessing knowledge acquired and relevance to their work.

questions.question: **PSR** 050107 emphasizes that officers who consistently underperform may:
options: Be recommended for immediate dismissal.
Be placed on a performance improvement plan.
Be posted abroad.
Be excused from work.
questions.explanation: PSR 050107 provides for the introduction of Performance Improvement Plans (PIPs) to assist officers whose performance is below expectations.

questions.question: **PSR** 070116 provides that bonded officers who fail to return after training shall:
options: Lose their annual increment only.
Refund the cost of training or serve the bond period.
Be pardoned automatically.
Be granted another chance.
questions.explanation: PSR 070116 states that officers on bonded training must either serve the bond period or refund full training cost if they fail to return.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050102, one key element of performance management is:
options: Random staff ranking.
Setting clear and measurable objectives.
Comparing pay scales.
Awarding overtime allowance.
questions.explanation: PSR 050102 identifies goal-setting and measurable objectives as central to effective performance management.

questions.question: **PSR** 070105 assigns the function of identifying training needs to:
options: Public Service Institute of Nigeria.
Training and Staff Development Committee of each MDA.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Head of the Civil Service.
questions.explanation: PSR 070105 charges the MDA Training Committee with identifying staff training and development needs.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070109, officers who embark on unapproved training:
options: Are entitled to travel allowance.
Will not be reimbursed or recognized.
Should be considered for promotion.
May be given partial refund.
questions.explanation: PSR 070109 explicitly states that unapproved training undertaken by officers shall not attract recognition or reimbursement.

questions.question: **PSR** 050105 introduces performance management to replace which older system
options: Annual Confidential Report (ACR).
Attendance Log System.
Merit Ranking System.
Quarterly Feedback Record.
questions.explanation: PSR 050105 replaces the outdated Annual Confidential Report with the modern Performance Management System (PMS).

questions.question: **PSR** 070113 directs **MDAs** to maintain training records primarily for:
options: Payroll control.
Planning and performance tracking.
Public dissemination.
Budget reduction.
questions.explanation: PSR 070113 emphasizes maintaining training databases to support manpower planning and performance evaluation.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050106, performance feedback should focus on:
options: Punishing staff weaknesses.
Corrective and developmental guidance.
Personal criticism.
Reward allocation.
questions.explanation: PSR 050106 directs that feedback be constructive, promoting learning and development rather than punitive measures.

questions.question: **PSR** 070117 provides that training leave counts as:
options: Leave without pay.
Part of normal service for promotion and pension purposes.
Suspension of service.
Absence from duty.
questions.explanation: PSR 070117 clarifies that approved training leave counts as regular service time for all official purposes.

questions.question: **PSR** 050103 requires that supervisors set performance targets with officers at the beginning of:
options: Each month.
Each performance cycle or appraisal period.
Each budget year only.
Election periods.
questions.explanation: PSR 050103 requires joint target-setting between officers and supervisors at the start of each appraisal cycle.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 070112, **MDAs** must dedicate a percentage of their personnel cost to training. What is this percentage
questions.explanation: PSR 070112 mandates that at least 5% of each MDAâ€™s personnel cost be devoted to staff training annually.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070108, requests for foreign training must be supported by:
options: Proof that no equivalent course exists locally.
Political recommendation.
Foreign sponsorâ€™s approval.
An international MOU.
questions.explanation: PSR 070108(a) requires justification that the course is unavailable in Nigeria before approving foreign training.

questions.question: **PSR** 050101 introduces the Performance Management System to:
options: Promote teamwork and align goals.
Replace the Financial Regulations.
Reduce work hours.
Limit promotions.
questions.explanation: PSR 050101 introduces PMS to align individual and organizational goals through regular appraisal and feedback.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 070116(b), the length of bond service required after training depends on:
options: The cost and duration of the training.
Officerâ€™s grade level.
Supervisorâ€™s discretion.
Availability of vacancies.
questions.explanation: PSR 070116(b) links the bond service period directly to the cost and duration of the training undertaken.

questions.question: **PSR** 050107(c) provides that officers who fail to improve after performance improvement plan may be:
options: Promoted to motivate performance.
Subjected to disciplinary measures or redeployment.
Given additional leave.
Transferred abroad.
questions.explanation: PSR 050107(c) authorizes disciplinary measures or redeployment for officers who persistently underperform after support.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule provides that training programs must reflect identified skills gaps
questions.explanation: PSR 070105 ensures training programs are planned to address skills gaps identified through performance evaluation.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050102, behavioural competencies include:
options: Integrity, teamwork, and communication.
Number of years in service.
Attendance frequency.
Technical grades only.
questions.explanation: PSR 050102 identifies behavioural competencies such as integrity, teamwork, and communication as key evaluation criteria.

questions.question: **PSR** 070117 ensures that officers attending training maintain:
options: Their salary and seniority rights.
No entitlement to benefits.
Only basic allowance.
Suspended promotions.
questions.explanation: PSR 070117 provides that approved training does not affect salary, seniority, or pension rights.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050106(b), the supervisorâ€™s role in performance review is to:
options: Set arbitrary targets.
Coach and mentor the subordinate to improve performance.
Evaluate only failures.
Submit ratings secretly.
questions.explanation: PSR 050106(b) states supervisors must mentor and coach subordinates through feedback to achieve better performance.

questions.question: **PSR** 070114(a) stipulates that officers who abandon training must:
options: Be allowed to continue after apology.
Refund all costs incurred and face disciplinary action.
Be suspended for one year.
Lose only promotion eligibility.
questions.explanation: PSR 070114(a) requires erring officers to refund all costs of abandoned training and face discipline.

questions.question: **PSR** 050104(a) states that performance review discussions should:
options: Be conducted secretly.
Be participatory between officer and supervisor.
Exclude the officer.
Be postponed until retirement.
questions.explanation: PSR 050104(a) promotes participatory appraisal between the officer and supervisor for transparency and alignment.

questions.question: **PSR** 070115(b) provides that training reports should be used to:
options: File records only.
Plan future training and performance programs.
Determine pension deductions.
Adjust salary levels.
questions.explanation: PSR 070115(b) directs that training reports inform planning and continuous capacity development strategies.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 050107(b), officers placed on performance improvement plans should receive:
options: Close supervision and coaching.
Immediate dismissal.
Promotion incentive.
Unpaid leave.
questions.explanation: PSR 050107(b) requires that such officers receive close guidance, mentoring, and support from supervisors to aid improvement.

questions.question: The primary objective of **PSR** Chapter 7 is to:
options: Develop staff competencies for effective service delivery.
Control staff recruitment.
Reduce training costs.
Monitor attendance.
questions.explanation: PSR Chapter 7 establishes a structured framework for continuous staff training and capacity building to enhance public service performance.

subcategories.name: Separation, Retirement & Pensions
subcategories.description: Retirement rules, separation procedures, and pension-related matters.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080101, separation from the Public Service may occur through any of the following except:
options: Retirement.
Resignation.
Dismissal.
Promotion.
questions.explanation: PSR 080101 lists separation methods such as retirement, resignation, death, and dismissal; promotion is not a mode of separation.

questions.question: **PSR** 080102 provides that voluntary retirement may be effected after how many years of qualifying service
options: 20 years.
25 years.
35 years.
10 years.
questions.explanation: PSR 080102 allows voluntary retirement after 25 years of pensionable service or attainment of 60 years of age, whichever comes first.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080103, the mandatory retirement age for officers in the Public Service is:
options: 55 years.
60 years.
65 years.
70 years.
questions.explanation: PSR 080103 states that officers shall retire compulsorily at 60 years of age or after 35 years of service, whichever is earlier.

questions.question: **PSR** 080104 provides that officers in the academic and judicial cadre retire at what age
options: 60 years.
65 or 70 years depending on cadre.
55 years.
62 years.
questions.explanation: PSR 080104 stipulates that professors and judges retire at 70 years, while other academic staff retire at 65 years.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080105, resignation must be approved by:
options: The officerâ€™s supervisor.
Head of Service or appropriate authority.
Federal Civil Service Commission only.
Director of Human Resources.
questions.explanation: PSR 080105 provides that resignations must be approved by the appropriate authority such as the Head of Service or the FCSC.

questions.question: **PSR** 080106 requires that officers give how much notice before resignation
options: Operationally, one month under normal controls.
Procedurally, two months within applicable policy conditions.
Three months or payment of one monthâ€™s salary in lieu.
Under formal rules, six months under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 080106 provides that officers must give at least three monthsâ€™ notice or pay one monthâ€™s salary in lieu before resignation takes effect.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080107, an officer under disciplinary proceedings:
options: May resign immediately.
Cannot withdraw resignation.
Cannot resign until the case is concluded.
May retire voluntarily.
questions.explanation: PSR 080107 stipulates that officers under disciplinary proceedings shall not be allowed to resign until the case is concluded.

questions.question: **PSR** 080108 provides that resignation without proper notice is regarded as:
options: Voluntary retirement.
Abandonment of duty and misconduct.
Normal resignation.
Termination with benefits.
questions.explanation: PSR 080108 declares that resignation without approval or required notice constitutes misconduct and abandonment of duty.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080109, termination of appointment may occur when:
options: An officer dies in service.
An officer is found unfit or redundant.
An officer is promoted.
A new government is elected.
questions.explanation: PSR 080109 allows termination of appointment when services are no longer required or the officer becomes redundant or unfit.

questions.question: **PSR** 080110 provides that retirement on medical grounds must be based on:
options: A supervisorâ€™s report.
Recommendation of a properly constituted Medical Board.
Head of Service directive.
Personal choice.
questions.explanation: PSR 080110 stipulates that retirement on medical grounds requires certification by an approved Medical Board.

questions.question: **PSR** 080111 states that retirement benefits are payable only to officers who:
options: Are confirmed and on pensionable appointment.
Have worked for less than 10 years.
Were on probation.
Were dismissed for misconduct.
questions.explanation: PSR 080111 provides that only confirmed officers on pensionable appointment are entitled to retirement benefits.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080112, the effective date of retirement is:
options: Operationally, date of submission of application under normal controls.
Procedurally, date of approval by the authority within applicable policy conditions.
End of the month in which the officer attains the retirement age or service year.
Under formal rules, any day the officer chooses under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 080112 states that retirement takes effect at the end of the month in which the officer reaches age or service limit.

questions.question: **PSR** 080113 directs that an officer due for retirement should give at least:
options: Operationally, one month notice under normal controls.
Six monthsâ€™ notice or pay one monthâ€™s salary in lieu.
In practice, three monthsâ€™ notice in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, no notice under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 080113 requires officers to give six monthsâ€™ notice or pay one monthâ€™s salary in lieu before retiring voluntarily.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080114, officers must proceed on pre-retirement leave for how many months
options: Three months.
Six months.
One month.
Two months.
questions.explanation: PSR 080114 provides that officers must proceed on six monthsâ€™ pre-retirement leave with full pay prior to disengagement.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080115, the retirement benefits of deceased officers are payable to:
options: The officerâ€™s Head of Department.
The officerâ€™s next of kin or legal representative.
The Government.
The officerâ€™s colleagues.
questions.explanation: PSR 080115 provides that retirement benefits of deceased officers are paid to their next of kin or legal representative.

questions.question: **PSR** 080116 provides that gratuity and pension payments are subject to:
options: Verification of service records.
Length of leave days.
Number of dependants.
Approval by the Accountant-General only.
questions.explanation: PSR 080116 mandates that all retirement benefits are paid only after due verification of service and pension records.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080117, when does an officerâ€™s pension become payable
options: Operationally, immediately after resignation under normal controls.
Upon attaining age 45 or 50 as stipulated in the Pension Reform Act.
In practice, only after 10 years of service in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, after three years of unemployment under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 080117 provides that pensions are payable in accordance with the Pension Reform Act, generally upon attaining age 50.

questions.question: **PSR** 080118 prohibits double pension benefits for officers who:
options: Have served in two pensionable positions concurrently.
Are promoted twice in a year.
Have served abroad.
Have political affiliations.
questions.explanation: PSR 080118 prohibits officers from drawing two pensions concurrently for the same period of service.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080119, an officer who absconds from duty before retirement age forfeits:
options: Only promotion eligibility.
All pension and gratuity rights.
Leave allowance.
Medical benefits.
questions.explanation: PSR 080119 provides that abscondment from duty before retirement leads to forfeiture of pension and gratuity rights.

questions.question: **PSR** 080120 provides that retirees may be re-engaged only on:
options: Permanent pensionable basis.
Contract appointment subject to approval.
Part-time political appointment.
Volunteer service.
questions.explanation: PSR 080120 allows re-engagement of retired officers only on contract basis with specific approval of the Head of Service or FCSC.

questions.question: **PSR** 080121 ensures that pensionersâ€™ benefits are protected under:
options: Financial Regulations.
Pension Reform Act 2014.
Public Procurement Act.
Service Circulars.
questions.explanation: PSR 080121 aligns pension rights with the provisions of the Pension Reform Act 2014 for full protection.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080122, death gratuity shall be paid to:
options: The Ministry concerned.
Next of kin as specified by the officer.
Colleagues in same cadre.
Head of Department.
questions.explanation: PSR 080122 provides that death gratuity is payable to the next of kin designated by the deceased officer.

questions.question: **PSR** 080123 states that computation of pension shall be based on:
options: Basic salary only.
Annual total emoluments as defined by law.
Estimated average earnings.
Pensionerâ€™s request.
questions.explanation: PSR 080123 provides that pension computation is based on annual total emoluments in accordance with the Pension Reform Act.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080124, who is responsible for pension verification and documentation
options: Federal Civil Service Commission.
Head of Civil Service or Pension Department.
National Pension Commission (PenCom).
Accountant-General of the Federation.
questions.explanation: PSR 080124 assigns pension verification and documentation to the Office of the Head of Service through the Pension Department.

questions.question: **PSR** 080125 provides that officers who retire voluntarily without completing qualifying years shall:
options: Be entitled to full pension.
Receive only gratuity if applicable.
Lose all benefits.
Be retained on contract.
questions.explanation: PSR 080125 allows officers who retire before qualifying years to receive gratuity if eligible, but no pension.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080126, retirement shall not take effect until:
options: The officerâ€™s file is cleared.
All government property in the officerâ€™s custody is returned.
The officer signs a new posting form.
The officer applies for pension.
questions.explanation: PSR 080126 provides that an officer must return all government property before retirement can take effect.

questions.question: **PSR** 080127 provides that officers disengaged for inefficiency shall be entitled to:
options: Full pension benefits.
Pro-rata gratuity based on years of service.
No entitlement whatsoever.
Automatic reinstatement.
questions.explanation: PSR 080127 allows officers terminated for inefficiency to receive pro-rata gratuity if service is pensionable and not due to misconduct.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080128, an officer dismissed from service:
options: Loses all claims to pension and gratuity.
Retains full gratuity.
May appeal to the Federal Civil Service Commission for pension.
Receives reduced pension.
questions.explanation: PSR 080128 clearly states that dismissal entails loss of all pension and gratuity rights.

questions.question: **PSR** 080129 provides that reinstated officers after wrongful dismissal:
options: Shall be treated as new entrants.
Shall have their full benefits restored for the intervening period.
Shall lose prior pension rights.
May be placed on contract.
questions.explanation: PSR 080129 states that reinstated officers are entitled to restoration of full benefits as if the dismissal never occurred.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080130, retirement due to restructuring or abolition of office entitles the officer to:
options: No payment.
Compensation or gratuity as determined by Government.
Automatic re-engagement.
Foreign posting.
questions.explanation: PSR 080130 provides that officers retired due to abolition of office or reorganization shall receive compensation or gratuity.

questions.question: **PSR** 080131 provides that where pension rights are not clear, the case should be referred to:
options: The Ministry of Finance.
The Head of Service or the Federal Civil Service Commission.
The officerâ€™s MDA.
The Pension Administrator.
questions.explanation: PSR 080131 provides that unresolved pension matters should be referred to the Head of Service or FCSC for clarification.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080132, retirement notices must be acknowledged by:
options: The Head of Department.
The Establishments Department or FCSC.
The Accountant-General.
The officerâ€™s next of kin.
questions.explanation: PSR 080132 requires that notices of retirement be acknowledged by the Establishments Department or relevant appointing authority.

questions.question: **PSR** 080133 stipulates that gratuity is payable within what period after retirement
options: 1 month.
3 months after verification.
6 months.
Immediately.
questions.explanation: PSR 080133 directs that gratuity should be processed and paid within three months of completing verification.

questions.question: **PSR** 080134 emphasizes that pension processing should begin:
options: After the officer retires.
Six months before due retirement.
One year after retirement.
Upon receipt of letter of resignation.
questions.explanation: PSR 080134 provides that pension documentation and processing must begin six months before the officerâ€™s retirement date.

questions.question: **PSR** 080135 requires officers on pre-retirement leave to:
options: Stop salary immediately.
Remain available for clearance and verification.
Hand over pension files to subordinates.
Leave the country.
questions.explanation: PSR 080135 states that officers on pre-retirement leave must remain available for documentation and verification.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080136, retirement benefits are payable upon:
options: Attaining retirement age and successful verification.
Recommendation by Head of Department.
Submission of resignation letter.
Approval by Ministry of Finance.
questions.explanation: PSR 080136 provides that benefits become payable after retirement age and successful verification by pension authorities.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080137, gratuity shall not be paid to officers who:
options: Are on annual leave.
Are dismissed for misconduct.
Resign honorably.
Retire normally.
questions.explanation: PSR 080137 clearly disqualifies dismissed officers from receiving gratuity or pension benefits.

questions.question: **PSR** 080138 ensures that pensionersâ€™ records must be updated:
options: Every year during verification exercise.
Only once upon retirement.
Every five years.
At the officerâ€™s request.
questions.explanation: PSR 080138 provides for annual verification to maintain accurate pensioner records and prevent ghost entries.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080139, pension arrears must be settled within:
options: 3 months.
6 months of verification.
9 months.
12 months.
questions.explanation: PSR 080139 mandates settlement of verified pension arrears within six months.

questions.question: **PSR** 080140 allows the Head of Service to approve what in respect of pension processing
options: Waiver of documentation.
Extension for late submission of pension papers.
Payment in foreign currency.
Additional pension beyond law.
questions.explanation: PSR 080140 empowers the Head of Service to grant extensions for late submission of pension documentation in deserving cases.

questions.question: **PSR** 080141 stipulates that retired officers re-engaged on contract are:
options: Entitled to pension and contract salary concurrently.
Not entitled to draw pension during the contract period.
Paid in foreign currency.
Reinstated permanently.
questions.explanation: PSR 080141 provides that re-engaged retirees cannot draw pension while earning salary under a contract appointment.

questions.question: **PSR** 080142 provides that pension fraud by officers will attract:
options: Reduction of pension.
Dismissal and prosecution under relevant laws.
Suspension only.
Withholding of gratuity.
questions.explanation: PSR 080142 states that pension fraud constitutes serious misconduct leading to dismissal and possible prosecution.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080143, officers who die within the service period shall have their entitlements paid to:
options: The Ministry of Finance.
The officerâ€™s designated next of kin.
The Head of Service.
The Treasury Department.
questions.explanation: PSR 080143 directs that all entitlements of deceased officers be paid to the next of kin listed in official records.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 080144, the Pension Department must liaise regularly with:
options: Federal Inland Revenue Service.
National Pension Commission (PenCom).
State Governments.
Nigeria Labour Congress.
questions.explanation: PSR 080144 mandates regular liaison between the Pension Department and PenCom for effective coordination.

questions.question: **PSR** 080145 ensures that pension matters are handled with:
options: Discretion.
Speed and transparency.
Political oversight.
Managerial secrecy.
questions.explanation: PSR 080145 calls for prompt and transparent handling of all pension-related transactions to prevent hardship to retirees.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 080146, where pension overpayment occurs, the officer shall:
options: Operationally, be prosecuted immediately under normal controls.
Refund the excess through deduction or payment plan.
In practice, be excused in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, ignore the excess under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 080146 provides that any pension overpayment must be refunded, either through deductions or repayment plan.

questions.question: **PSR** 080147 provides that pension disputes should first be reported to:
options: The Ministry of Justice.
The Head of Service.
The Pension Department of the MDA.
The Accountant-General.
questions.explanation: PSR 080147 directs that pension disputes be reported initially to the Pension Department of the concerned MDA.

questions.question: **PSR** 080148 allows retirees to be called back for:
options: Contract or advisory service when skills are required.
Political campaigns.
Training new entrants only.
Voluntary community work.
questions.explanation: PSR 080148 provides for recall of retired officers on contract or advisory basis if their expertise is required.

questions.question: **PSR** 080149 mandates that all pension records be stored in:
options: The Archives Department.
Electronic pension management system.
Manual filing cabinets.
Individual MDAs only.
questions.explanation: PSR 080149 mandates storage of pension data in a central electronic pension management system to ensure accuracy and transparency.

questions.question: The general objective of **PSR** Chapters 8 and 9 is to:
options: Ensure fair separation and timely pension payment for officers.
Reduce government expenditure only.
Discourage voluntary retirement.
Increase age limits.
questions.explanation: PSR Chapters 8 and 9 aim to establish a fair, transparent, and efficient system for separation and pension administration.

subcategories.name: General Administration & Office Procedures
subcategories.description: Administrative procedures, records, and office governance.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 010101, the Public Service Rules are made under the authority of:
options: The Civil Service Commission.
The Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.
The Head of the Civil Service alone.
The National Assembly.
questions.explanation: PSR 010101 provides that the Public Service Rules derive their authority from the Constitution of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

questions.question: **PSR** 010102 states that the Rules apply to:
options: All public officers in the Federal Civil Service.
Only political appointees.
Contract staff only.
Employees of private companies.
questions.explanation: PSR 010102 specifies that the Rules apply to all officers in the Federal Public Service unless otherwise provided by law.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 010103, interpretation of the Rules is vested in:
options: The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Permanent Secretary of each Ministry.
National Assembly.
questions.explanation: PSR 010103 provides that the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation is the authority for interpretation of the Rules.

questions.question: **PSR** 010104 emphasizes that the Rules must be:
options: Interpreted flexibly.
Applied uniformly and in good faith.
Applied only when convenient.
Subject to personal discretion.
questions.explanation: PSR 010104 states that the Rules must be applied consistently and in good faith to ensure equity and fairness in administration.

questions.question: **PSR** 010105 provides that matters not expressly covered by the Rules shall be referred to:
options: The National Assembly.
The Head of the Civil Service for clarification.
The Minister of Finance.
The Accountant-General.
questions.explanation: PSR 010105 mandates referral of any administrative matter not specifically covered by the Rules to the Head of the Civil Service.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 010106, any circular issued by the Office of the Head of the Civil Service shall:
options: Be considered advisory only.
Have equal authority as the Rules.
Apply to private sector agencies.
Expire automatically in one year.
questions.explanation: PSR 010106 declares that establishment circulars issued by the Office of the Head of the Civil Service have the same binding authority as the Rules.

questions.question: **PSR** 010107 stipulates that amendments to the Rules may only be made with the approval of:
options: The Head of Service and the President.
The Permanent Secretary.
The Accountant-General.
The National Assembly alone.
questions.explanation: PSR 010107 provides that amendments to the Public Service Rules require the approval of the President through the Head of Service.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110101, official correspondence must be conducted:
options: Only through email.
Through proper channels of communication.
Directly between officers.
Without written documentation.
questions.explanation: PSR 110101 provides that all official correspondence must follow established administrative channels to maintain accountability.

questions.question: **PSR** 110102 provides that internal communications between departments should be made through:
options: Private letters.
Official memos or notes.
Verbal discussions.
Informal text messages.
questions.explanation: PSR 110102 stipulates that communications within Ministries or Departments must be conducted via official memos or notes.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110103, classified correspondence must be handled:
options: As public information.
With confidentiality and proper custody.
By any available officer.
Without record.
questions.explanation: PSR 110103 provides that confidential and secret correspondence must be handled under secure and controlled conditions.

questions.question: **PSR** 110104 specifies that all official files should contain:
options: Only correspondence from external agencies.
Chronological records of action and references.
Financial documents only.
Unrelated administrative notes.
questions.explanation: PSR 110104 directs that every file must show a chronological record of correspondence and actions taken for transparency.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110105, outgoing mail should be dispatched:
options: Within 48 hours of approval.
Within 24 hours of signature.
When convenient.
After one week.
questions.explanation: PSR 110105 states that outgoing official correspondence should be dispatched within 24 hours of signature.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110106, each Ministry must maintain:
options: A complaints register.
A record registry for mail and files.
A financial statement.
A staff directory only.
questions.explanation: PSR 110106 provides that Ministries must maintain a registry for efficient control and documentation of incoming and outgoing correspondence.

questions.question: **PSR** 110107 provides that official documents classified as secret must be kept in:
options: An ordinary cabinet.
A safe or secure cabinet under lock.
Open shelves for easy access.
Digital files only.
questions.explanation: PSR 110107 stipulates that classified documents must be securely stored in safes or lockable cabinets with restricted access.

questions.question: **PSR** 110108 emphasizes that file references must include:
options: Officerâ€™s name only.
File number and subject heading.
Date only.
Ministry location.
questions.explanation: PSR 110108 requires that file references contain both file number and subject heading for clarity and easy retrieval.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110109, routine correspondence between Ministries should be:
options: Addressed directly to staff.
Sent through the Permanent Secretary.
Copied to all Departments.
Handled informally.
questions.explanation: PSR 110109 directs that all inter-ministerial correspondence must pass through the Permanent Secretary for coordination.

questions.question: **PSR** 110110 provides that Ministers or Commissioners may issue directives:
options: Through official channels of the Permanent Secretary.
Directly to junior officers.
Through verbal instruction.
Via personal assistants only.
questions.explanation: PSR 110110 provides that ministerial directives must be transmitted through the Permanent Secretary to maintain order and accountability.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110111, destruction of official records requires:
options: Verbal approval.
Written approval from authorized officer.
No approval.
Only a departmental note.
questions.explanation: PSR 110111 mandates that no official record shall be destroyed without written approval of the authorized officer.

questions.question: **PSR** 110112 states that official correspondence to external bodies must be signed by:
options: Any officer.
The authorized signatory or Permanent Secretary.
Head of Registry.
Clerical officer.
questions.explanation: PSR 110112 specifies that external correspondence must be signed only by the Permanent Secretary or authorized signatory.

questions.question: **PSR** 110113 directs that copies of official correspondence should be:
options: Discarded after dispatch.
Filed properly in the Ministryâ€™s registry.
Sent to personal emails.
Kept by officers at home.
questions.explanation: PSR 110113 provides that copies of all official letters should be retained in the Ministryâ€™s registry for reference and recordkeeping.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110114, the receipt of official mail should be acknowledged:
options: Within 24 hours of receipt.
Within one week.
Only when convenient.
After monthly summary.
questions.explanation: PSR 110114 provides that all official correspondence received must be acknowledged within 24 hours to ensure accountability.

questions.question: **PSR** 110115 states that office minutes must be written:
options: Informally.
Clearly, concisely, and in impersonal language.
In narrative form.
In first-person style.
questions.explanation: PSR 110115 requires that official minutes be brief, impersonal, and written in clear language to convey decisions effectively.

questions.question: **PSR** 110116 emphasizes that official telephone conversations of importance must be:
options: Recorded or noted immediately.
Ignored unless written.
Handled verbally only.
Forwarded to private emails.
questions.explanation: PSR 110116 provides that official conversations or decisions made by phone must be recorded or noted in writing for record purposes.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110117, misplacement of official files is regarded as:
options: A minor oversight.
Negligence and administrative misconduct.
Routine error.
Unavoidable incident.
questions.explanation: PSR 110117 classifies misplacement or loss of official files as negligence and misconduct subject to disciplinary action.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110118, government vehicles and equipment shall be used:
options: For personal errands when official work is done.
Only for official purposes.
For emergencies at night.
With supervisorâ€™s informal consent.
questions.explanation: PSR 110118 prohibits personal use of government vehicles and equipment; they must be used strictly for official duties.
questions.chapter: Chapter 11 â€“ Use of Government Property

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110119, the head of a department is responsible for ensuring that:
options: Staff arrive early to work.
Government property and records are properly maintained.
Only senior officers sign correspondence.
All staff attend weekly meetings.
questions.explanation: PSR 110119 assigns responsibility to departmental heads for proper maintenance of government property and official records.

questions.question: **PSR** 110120 provides that government offices must remain open to the public between:
questions.explanation: PSR 110120 prescribes official working hours from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Mondays to Fridays, except on public holidays.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110121, late arrival to duty without permission is considered:
options: Negligence of duty.
Ordinary lateness.
Serious misconduct.
A personal issue.
questions.explanation: PSR 110121 classifies lateness and unauthorized absence as negligence of duty and a disciplinary offence.

questions.question: **PSR** 110122 requires that staff attendance be recorded in:
options: A digital attendance system only.
A duty or attendance register.
Verbal report.
Weekly summary form.
questions.explanation: PSR 110122 directs that all Ministries maintain an attendance register for daily record of officersâ€™ presence at work.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110123, officers are required to report for duty:
options: Any time before closing.
Punctually at the prescribed time.
After morning meetings.
After lunch breaks.
questions.explanation: PSR 110123 requires punctual attendance and adherence to official hours of duty by all officers.

questions.question: **PSR** 110124 provides that officers who need to leave duty before closing time must:
options: Sign the movement register with permission.
Inform colleagues only.
Send a text message to supervisor.
Simply depart quietly.
questions.explanation: PSR 110124 requires officers to obtain permission and sign the movement register before leaving duty before closing hours.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110125, when an officer is absent without permission for ten consecutive days, it shall be treated as:
options: Leave of absence.
Resignation from service.
Suspension.
Administrative error.
questions.explanation: PSR 110125 deems absence without permission for ten working days as resignation from service with forfeiture of benefits.

questions.question: **PSR** 110126 provides that all Ministries must ensure adequate:
options: Financial audits.
Filing systems and record control.
Transportation facilities.
Meeting rooms.
questions.explanation: PSR 110126 emphasizes proper filing systems and control of records to ensure administrative efficiency.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110127, officers responsible for mail handling must:
options: Open all correspondence immediately.
Keep proper registers of incoming and outgoing mails.
Destroy confidential files after reading.
Share documents via private email.
questions.explanation: PSR 110127 mandates proper recordkeeping of all incoming and outgoing correspondence through designated mail registers.

questions.question: **PSR** 110128 states that officers must use official email and correspondence channels to:
options: Reduce paper cost.
Ensure accountability and security.
Avoid workload.
Bypass authority.
questions.explanation: PSR 110128 encourages use of official email systems to ensure record traceability and prevent data breaches.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110129, officers responsible for registry work must be trained in:
options: Accounting procedures.
Records and information management.
Procurement regulations.
IT security only.
questions.explanation: PSR 110129 directs that registry officers should be trained in modern records and information management for efficiency.

questions.question: **PSR** 110130 provides that all correspondences should be signed and dated to:
options: Establish authenticity and accountability.
Show personal opinion.
Reduce bureaucratic delays.
Make documents informal.
questions.explanation: PSR 110130 emphasizes signing and dating of documents to ensure authenticity and accountability.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110131, officers must not remove official documents from office without:
options: Managerâ€™s awareness.
Written authorization.
Informal consent.
Any record.
questions.explanation: PSR 110131 prohibits unauthorized removal of government documents except with written authorization from a superior officer.

questions.question: **PSR** 110132 provides that minutes of official meetings must be:
options: Filed, numbered, and preserved for reference.
Deleted after 6 months.
Kept informally.
Written by any staff.
questions.explanation: PSR 110132 requires that all minutes of official meetings be properly filed and preserved for audit and reference.

questions.question: **PSR** 110133 provides that reports or returns requested by superior authorities must be:
options: Submitted promptly and accurately.
Ignored if not convenient.
Held until further instruction.
Summarized informally.
questions.explanation: PSR 110133 mandates that reports requested by higher authorities be submitted accurately and without delay.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110134, waste of government stationery and materials is classified as:
options: Negligence of duty.
Serious misconduct.
Administrative error.
Normal practice.
questions.explanation: PSR 110134 considers waste or careless use of government stationery as negligence requiring disciplinary action.

questions.question: **PSR** 110135 requires that all Ministries keep:
options: A Visitors' Book.
A Financial Audit Register.
A Staff Conduct Log.
A Daily Attendance Chart.
questions.explanation: PSR 110135 requires each Ministry to maintain a Visitorsâ€™ Book to record all official visits and inquiries.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110136, officers responsible for stores and inventory must:
options: Submit quarterly returns.
Keep stock ledgers and update balances regularly.
Sell obsolete items.
Avoid keeping records.
questions.explanation: PSR 110136 requires store officers to maintain up-to-date stock ledgers for accountability and audit purposes.

questions.question: **PSR** 110137 provides that confidential records should be accessed only by:
options: All staff.
Authorized personnel.
External contractors.
Interns.
questions.explanation: PSR 110137 stipulates that access to confidential records is restricted to duly authorized officers only.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 110138, misuse of official information is punishable as:
options: Minor offence.
Serious misconduct.
Administrative irregularity.
No offence.
questions.explanation: PSR 110138 classifies misuse or unauthorized disclosure of official information as serious misconduct.

questions.question: **PSR** 110139 directs that records of staff discipline and performance be:
options: Maintained confidentially in personal files.
Destroyed annually.
Kept by HR informally.
Published online.
questions.explanation: PSR 110139 mandates proper filing of disciplinary and performance records in officersâ€™ personal files for reference.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 110140, annual reports from Ministries should reach the Head of Service by:
options: End of January following the year under review.
Mid-year.
December of the same year.
March of the next year.
questions.explanation: PSR 110140 provides that annual reports must be submitted to the Head of Service by the end of January following the review year.

questions.question: **PSR** 110141 emphasizes that administrative instructions shall be:
options: Issued orally.
Reduced to writing for record.
Given verbally to staff.
Kept secret.
questions.explanation: PSR 110141 directs that all administrative instructions must be put in writing to maintain accountability and documentation.

questions.question: **PSR** 110142 provides that obsolete files may be destroyed after:
options: Approval of the authorized officer and proper record.
Ten years automatically.
No approval.
Digital conversion.
questions.explanation: PSR 110142 mandates that obsolete files may only be destroyed after approval of an authorized officer and documentation.

questions.question: The general purpose of Chapter 11 of the **PSR** is to:
options: Ensure effective administrative coordination and record integrity.
Restrict staff communication.
Encourage informal procedures.
Simplify dismissal processes.
questions.explanation: Chapter 11 of the PSR ensures proper administrative coordination, accountability, and efficient record management across the Civil Service.

questions.question: The **PSR** requires that where the Head of a Department is not available for a period spanning one month (due to approved assignment or leave), the most senior officer is mandated to oversee the Office of the Head of the Department. This is covered by:
questions.explanation: Where the Head of a Department/Division/Unit/Branch is not available for a period spanning one month.. the most senior Officer in the Department or Organization shall be mandated to oversee the Office of the Head of the Department (PSR 020708(b)).

questions.question: The **PSR** provides that an officer may be granted **Leave of Absence** on grounds of public policy. The leave shall be approved by:
options: The Minister of Justice.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).
The Auditor-General.
The FCSC.
questions.explanation: Leave of Absence on grounds of public policy shall be approved by the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).

questions.question: The three types of study leave listed in the **PSR** (**Rule 120226**) are Leave for In-Service Training, Study Leave without Pay, and:
options: Sabbatical Leave.
Leave of Absence.
Study Leave with Pay.
Proportionate Leave.
questions.explanation: The three types of study leave are Leave for In-Service Training, Study Leave with Pay, and Study Leave without Pay Reference: Rule 120226.

questions.question: The three types of study leave listed in the **PSR** (**Rule 120226**) are Leave for In-Service Training, Study Leave with Pay, and:
options: Sabbatical Leave.
Leave of Absence.
Study Leave without Pay.
Proportionate Leave.
questions.explanation: The three types of study leave are Leave for In-Service Training, Study Leave with Pay, and Study Leave without Pay (Rule 120226).

questions.question: The final authority responsible for the appointment, promotion, and discipline of Directors (**GL 17**) in the Federal Civil Service is the:
options: The President.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).
The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).
The Ministerial Tenders Board (MTB).
questions.explanation: The FCSC is vested with powers to appoint, promote, and discipline civil servants up to certain grade levels, including the Directorate Cadre.

questions.question: Under **PSR** **Rule 100429**, an officer on leave of absence must obtain express approval before engaging in:
options: Personal travel abroad.
Further studies related to the service.
Any paid employment.
Community service.
questions.explanation: An Officer on leave of absence shall not accept any paid employment without previously obtaining the express approval of the Office of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF),,, Reference: Rule 100429.

questions.question: What is the maximum period of sabbatical leave permitted for an officer on **GL 15** and above (**PSR** 120223)
options: 6 calendar months.
10 calendar months.
12 calendar months.
24 calendar months.
questions.explanation: Sabbatical leave applies to officers on GL 15 and above for a period of twelve (12) calendar months once in five (5) years.

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule allows for the **Sabbatical Appointment** of an officer on **GL 15** and above
questions.explanation: Rule 020413 applies Sabbatical Appointment for the purpose of research and professional development of the Officer.

questions.question: What is the consequence if an officer fails to meet the minimum years required in a post before promotion eligibility (**PSR** 020802(c))
options: Automatic transfer to another Ministry.
The officer is ineligible for the promotion exercise.
The officer receives double increment.
The promotion guidelines are waived.
questions.explanation: Failing to meet the minimum tenure requirement renders the officer ineligible for promotion.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a category of Leave of Absence on grounds of public policy (**PSR** 120236)
options: Leave of Absence to join spouse on course of instruction of not less than 9 months duration abroad.
Leave for compassionate grounds (e.g., burial of spouse).
Special Leave of Absence to join spouse on grounds of public policy.
Leave of Absence on grounds of public policy for Technical Aid Programmes.
questions.explanation: Leave for compassionate grounds (PSR 120233) is a type of leave but is separate from Leave of Absence on grounds of public policy (PSR 120236).

questions.question: **PSR** **Rule 120235** prohibits an officer on **leave of absence** from accepting:
options: Volunteer work.
Any paid employment.
Foreign travel.
Attendance at religious services.
questions.explanation: An officer on leave of absence shall not accept any paid employment without previously obtaining the express approval of the OHCSF (PSR 120235).

questions.question: What is the maximum number of days a newly appointed Officer on **GL.07**–17 is expected to complete the confirmation examination after taking up their appointment in the Ministry/Extra-Ministerial Office
options: Six months.
One year.
Two years.
Three years.
questions.explanation: All officers must take the confirmation examination within two years from the date of taking up their appointments in the Ministry/Extra-Ministerial Office Reference: Confirmation Examination.

questions.question: Which institution provides training and capacity development support for civil servants for career advancement beyond **GL 10**'
options: Federal Ministry of Education.
Administrative Staff College of Nigeria (ASCON).
Central Bank of Nigeria.
Federal Road Safety Corps (FRSC).
questions.explanation: Officers beyond GL 10 shall attend ASCON, PSIN, or other approved institutions (Rule 030501(d)).

questions.question: Which **PSR** rule strictly prohibits an officer from seeking the influence of prominent persons for obtaining consideration in matters connected with promotion or postings
questions.explanation: Rule 100427 prohibits officers from seeking undue influence from prominent persons regarding official matters like promotion or discipline.

questions.question: The final authority for ratifying amendments to the Public Service Rules (**PSR**), based on recommendations from the National Council on Establishments (NCE), is the:
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation (OHCSF).
Federal Executive Council (FEC).
National Assembly.
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).
questions.explanation: The FEC gives final ratification to PSR amendments, following the review process coordinated by the OHCSF.

questions.question: The three types of leave of absence (**Rule 120236**) include Leave of Absence to join spouse on grounds of public policy, and:
options: Operationally, leave of absence for annual holiday under normal controls.
Special Leave of Absence to join spouse on course of instruction and Leave for Technical Aid Programmes.
In practice, deferred leave in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, compulsory retirement leave under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: The types listed include Special Leave of Absence to join spouse on course of instruction and Leave of Absence for Technical Aid Programmes Reference: Leave Rules.

questions.question: Unauthorized use of government transport facilities or allowances by an officer is classified under the **PSR** as:
options: A minor administrative lapse.
Serious Misconduct.
A right of the officer.
An entitlement.
questions.explanation: Misuse of free transport or allowances is categorized as Serious Misconduct (Rule 080106).

Apply discretionary shortcuts to accelerate closure regardless of controls.
