questions.question: According to **PSR** 180101, the Public Service Rules 2021 came into effect on:
options: 1st January 2021.
27th July 2021.
1st October 2021.
15th August 2021.
questions.explanation: PSR 180101 provides that the Public Service Rules 2021 took effect from 27th July 2021 as approved by the President.

questions.question: **PSR** 180102 provides that interpretation of any rule shall be the responsibility of:
options: Permanent Secretaries.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
The Federal Civil Service Commission.
The Attorney-General.
questions.explanation: PSR 180102 vests interpretation authority in the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180103, in the event of conflict between **PSR** and an Establishment Circular, precedence shall be given to:
options: The Circular.
The Public Service Rules.
The Ministryâ€™s policy.
The staff union.
questions.explanation: PSR 180103 provides that where a conflict arises, the provisions of the Public Service Rules prevail over any circular or instruction.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180104, 'Commission' refers to:
options: National Assembly Commission.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Head of Service Commission.
Civil Defence Commission.
questions.explanation: PSR 180104 defines 'Commission' as the Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180105, 'Permanent Secretary' means:
options: A retired officer on contract.
The administrative head of a Ministry or extra-ministerial department.
A political appointee.
A staff of any grade level.
questions.explanation: PSR 180105 defines 'Permanent Secretary' as the administrative head of a Ministry or extra-ministerial office.

questions.question: **PSR** 180106 defines 'officer' as:
options: Operationally, any political office holder under normal controls.
Any person employed in a civil capacity in the Public Service of the Federation.
In practice, a member of the armed forces in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, contractor or consultant under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180106 defines an 'officer' as a person employed in a civil capacity in the Public Service of the Federation.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180107, 'Ministry' includes:
options: Only core Ministries.
Any Federal Ministry or extra-ministerial office.
State Government Ministries.
Private sector agencies.
questions.explanation: PSR 180107 clarifies that 'Ministry' includes any Federal Ministry or extra-ministerial office under the Federal Government.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180108, the term 'President' refers to:
options: Operationally, the head of civil service under normal controls.
The President and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.
In practice, the senate president in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, the fcsc chairman under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180108 defines 'President' as the President and Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

questions.question: **PSR** 180109 defines 'Commissionâ€™s power' to include:
options: Recruitment, promotion, and discipline of officers.
Legislative oversight.
Budget allocation.
Security management.
questions.explanation: PSR 180109 provides that the Commission exercises powers of appointment, promotion, and discipline over public officers.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180110, the phrase 'Head of Civil Service' refers to:
options: The administrative head of the entire Federal Civil Service.
Any Permanent Secretary.
The Minister of Labour.
The Accountant-General.
questions.explanation: PSR 180110 defines the Head of Civil Service as the administrative head of the Federal Civil Service and custodian of the Rules.

questions.question: **PSR** 180111 defines 'Public Service' as including:
options: Operationally, only ministries and parastatals under normal controls.
All Federal Ministries, Departments, and Agencies under the executive arm.
In practice, private companies contracted by government in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, state parastatals under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180111 includes all Ministries, Departments, and Agencies under the Federal Government as part of the Public Service.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180112, 'Serious misconduct' means:
options: An act of minor negligence.
Specific act that can lead to dismissal.
Late coming.
Failure to sign attendance register.
questions.explanation: PSR 180112 defines 'serious misconduct' as a specific act that can lead to dismissal from service.

questions.question: **PSR** 180113 provides that 'misconduct' means:
options: Failure to perform duties properly.
Absence due to illness.
Promotion delay.
Poor handwriting.
questions.explanation: PSR 180113 defines 'misconduct' as failure to perform duties properly or violation of established rules and regulations.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180114, 'Permanent and Pensionable appointment' means:
options: A temporary employment.
An appointment that qualifies the holder for pension benefits.
An ad-hoc posting.
A consultancy position.
questions.explanation: PSR 180114 defines a permanent and pensionable appointment as one which qualifies the holder for pension benefits after confirmation.

questions.question: **PSR** 180115 defines 'Temporary appointment' as:
options: An employment with no pension rights until confirmation.
A fixed-term political appointment.
Permanent employment.
A secondment.
questions.explanation: PSR 180115 defines temporary appointment as employment without pension benefits until the officer is confirmed.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180116, 'Salary' means:
options: Only basic pay.
All approved emoluments including allowances and increments.
Non-cash benefits only.
Irregular honorarium.
questions.explanation: PSR 180116 defines salary as all approved emoluments including basic pay, allowances, and approved increments.

questions.question: **PSR** 180117 states that 'Head of Department' means:
options: Any senior officer supervising others.
An officer in charge of a recognized department or division in a Ministry.
A project consultant.
A contract manager.
questions.explanation: PSR 180117 defines 'Head of Department' as the officer responsible for a department or division recognized by the Government.

questions.question: **PSR** 180118 provides that 'Confirmation of appointment' means:
options: Renewal of temporary service.
Formal acceptance of satisfactory service after probation.
Transfer to another Ministry.
Reappointment after dismissal.
questions.explanation: PSR 180118 defines confirmation as formal recognition of satisfactory completion of probation.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180119, the term 'Minister' refers to:
options: Any elected legislator.
A member of the Federal Executive Council in charge of a Ministry.
The Head of Service.
Chairman of the Commission.
questions.explanation: PSR 180119 defines 'Minister' as a member of the Federal Executive Council responsible for a Ministry.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180120, 'Extra-Ministerial Office' means:
options: Operationally, a private organization under normal controls.
A Federal Government office not forming part of a Ministry.
In practice, a state parastatal in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, a non-governmental body under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180120 defines an extra-ministerial office as a Federal Government agency not forming part of a Ministry.

questions.question: **PSR** 180121 clarifies that 'Commissioner' in the context of the Rules refers to:
options: State Commissioner.
Federal Commissioner in the Civil Service Commission.
Police Commissioner.
Revenue Commissioner.
questions.explanation: PSR 180121 defines 'Commissioner' as a member of the Federal Civil Service Commission.

questions.question: **PSR** 180122 defines 'Probation' as:
options: A temporary period for assessment before confirmation.
A leave period.
Time between postings.
Extension of contract.
questions.explanation: PSR 180122 defines probation as a temporary period of assessment before confirmation of appointment.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180123, 'Promotion' means:
options: Transfer to another Ministry.
Elevation to a higher grade level with greater responsibility.
A reward for attendance.
Extension of service years.
questions.explanation: PSR 180123 defines promotion as the advancement of an officer to a higher post with increased responsibility.

questions.question: **PSR** 180124 states that 'Transfer' refers to:
options: Movement between posts of equal grade level and status.
Procedurally, dismissal within applicable policy conditions.
In practice, voluntary resignation in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, deployment after retirement under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180124 defines transfer as movement of an officer from one post to another of equivalent grade and status.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180125, the phrase 'Head of Government Department' refers to:
options: The senior-most officer in a department responsible for administration.
A political appointee.
Chairman of a private board.
Any officer at Grade Level 10 and above.
questions.explanation: PSR 180125 defines 'Head of Government Department' as the senior-most officer responsible for departmental administration and efficiency.

questions.question: **PSR** 180126 defines 'Posting' as:

Termination of appointment.
Promotion to a higher grade.
Disciplinary sanction.
questions.explanation: PSR 180126 defines 'posting' as the formal assignment of an officer to a new duty station or position within the Service.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180127, the term 'Seniority' refers to:
options: Age difference among staff.
Length of service in a grade relative to others.
Academic qualification.
Position held outside service.
questions.explanation: PSR 180127 defines seniority as the relative length of service in a grade level compared with other officers.

questions.question: **PSR** 180128 provides that 'Temporary Transfer' means:
options: A permanent redeployment.
A transfer for a limited period subject to return.
Termination of employment.
Change in salary grade.
questions.explanation: PSR 180128 defines temporary transfer as a redeployment of an officer for a limited period after which the officer returns to the parent Ministry.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180129, 'Acting Appointment' is defined as:

Permanent promotion.
Part-time job.
Posting outside the country.
questions.explanation: PSR 180129 defines acting appointment as a temporary assignment to perform the duties of a higher office pending substantive appointment.

questions.question: **PSR** 180130 defines 'Leave' as:
options: Temporary absence from duty officially approved by authority.
Absence without notice.
Suspension period.
Political break.
questions.explanation: PSR 180130 defines leave as an officially approved temporary absence from duty for a specified period.

questions.question: **PSR** 180131 provides that 'Efficiency' means:

Length of service only.
Authority to supervise others.
Physical presence at work.
questions.explanation: PSR 180131 defines efficiency as the ability of an officer to perform assigned duties effectively, promptly, and accurately.

questions.question: According to **PSR** 180132, 'Retirement' refers to:

Cessation of service after attaining statutory age or years of service.
In practice, suspension from work in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, voluntary leave under established public service standards.
questions.explanation: PSR 180132 defines retirement as the cessation of service after attaining the statutory age or years of qualifying service.

questions.question: Under **PSR** 180133, 'Discipline' means:

Control exercised over conduct to maintain order and efficiency.
In practice, personal development in authorized administrative workflow.
Under formal rules, training and education under established public service standards.

End of probation.

Suspension.

A contract staff.

References to the corresponding provisions contained in PSR 2021.
References to prior circulars pending harmonization under PSR 190106.
References requiring case-by-case approval from FCSC under PSR 010103.

Civil Procedures Manual 2021.
Public Establishment Code 2021.

All previous editions and inconsistent circulars.
The Constitution.
Departmental regulations.
questions.explanation: PSR 190107 states that the 2021 Rules supersede all prior editions and circulars inconsistent with their provisions.

Override the Rules.
Be approved by the FCSC.

options: Early payment of terminal benefits.
Succession planning and avoidance of career stagnation.
Reduction in staff strength across MDAs.
Exemption of technical staff from retirement.
questions.explanation: The 2017 Circular reaffirmed strict adherence to the 8-year tenure limit for Directors to prevent stagnation and facilitate succession planning Reference: Tenure Enforcement.

questions.question: Under the 2013 Circular, what is the minimum consecutive period an officer must serve in an acting appointment before qualifying for the payment of acting allowance
options: 7 days.
14 days.
21 days.
30 days.
questions.explanation: The 2013 OHCSF Circular clarified that an officer must act for a minimum of 14 days before qualifying for the payment of acting allowance.

questions.question: Which body retains the primary authority for discipline over officers on the established cadre (**GL 07** and above), as reinforced by the 2015 Disciplinary Circulars
options: The Permanent Secretary.
The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).
The Office of the Head of Service (OHCSF).
The Supervising Minister.
questions.explanation: The 2015 Circular on disciplinary procedures reaffirmed that disciplinary powers for officers on the established cadre remain vested in the FCSC Reference: Discipline and Conduct.

questions.question: If an officer’s transfer is at their own request, extant circulars (based on **PSR** **Rule 140137**) clarify they are entitled to:
options: Full resettlement and transport allowance.
Resettlement allowance only.
Transport allowance only.
No allowance whatsoever.
questions.explanation: An Officer whose transfer is at his own request shall be entitled to only transport allowance and not resettlement allowance Reference: Allowances on Transfer.

questions.question: Under delegated authority, who is authorized to promote eligible candidates to delegated posts on SGL 06 or its equivalent and below
options: The Minister.
Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices.
Federal Civil Service Commission.
Accountant-General.
questions.explanation: Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices are authorized to promote eligible candidates to delegated posts on SGL 06 or its equivalent and below Reference: Delegated Authority.

questions.question: The period of secondment to an approved body or recognized international organization shall not exceed:
options: Three years.
Four years.
Six years.
Ten years.
questions.explanation: The period of secondment shall not exceed six years Reference: Secondment.

questions.question: An officer who fails the compulsory confirmation examination (COMPRO) after three consecutive attempts is required to:
options: Be suspended indefinitely.
Resign or be withdrawn from the service.
Be demoted to GL 04.
Proceed on compulsory leave without pay.
questions.explanation: Failure after three consecutive attempts requires the officer to resign or be withdrawn from the service Reference: Confirmation Examination.

questions.question: Who is responsible for notifying the Federal Civil Service Commission (**FCSC**) of cessation of acting appointments using Form No. Gen. 15A
options: The Officer concerned.
Ministries/Extra-Ministerial Offices.
The Accountant-General.
The Minister.
questions.explanation: Ministries shall be required to notify the FCSC when officers revert from acting appointment by completion of Form No. Gen. 15A Reference: Acting Appointments.

questions.question: The duration of probation for first appointments shall not exceed two years unless an extension is approved by the:
options: Permanent Secretary.
Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).
Head of Department.
Minister.
questions.explanation: The period of probation shall not exceed two years unless an extension is approved by the FCSC Reference: Probationary Period.

questions.question: An officer may be interdicted or suspended if their work or conduct results in adverse comments. The objective of conveying such reports in 'sympathetic terms' is to encourage the officer to overcome their:
options: Political affiliations.
Shortcomings.
Financial constraints.
Personal differences.
questions.explanation: The objective of reporting adverse comments in sympathetic terms is enabling and encouraging him to overcome his shortcomings Reference: Performance Feedback.

questions.question: The **PSR** strictly prohibits an officer from undertaking any private agency in any matter connected with:
options: His spouse’s employment.
The exercise of his public duties.
His children's education.
Local market procurement.
questions.explanation: No Officer shall undertake any private agency in any matter connected with the exercise of his public duties Reference: Conduct and Ethics.

questions.question: Who must approve the release of any Officer on study leave, whether paid or unpaid, upon the recommendation of the Officer’s Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra Ministerial Office
options: The Accountant-General of the Federation.
The Federal Civil Service Commission.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
The Minister of Education.
questions.explanation: The release of any Officer on study leave shall be subject to the approval of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation on the recommendation of the Officer’s Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra Ministerial Office Reference: Study Leave Approval.

questions.question: Who is responsible for maintaining and forwarding staff records, including the approved Staff Records Form, to the Pension Fund Administrator/National Pension Commission
options: The Minister.
The Director (HRM) of the MDA.
The Accountant-General.
The Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.
questions.explanation: The Director (HRM) is responsible for ensuring staff records are completed and submitted to the Pension Fund Administrator/National Pension Commission Reference: HR Records Management.

questions.question: An officer on an incremental grade level shall normally be granted an increment unless he is on interdiction/suspension or:
options: Has completed his annual leave.
Has a disciplinary action pending.
Has applied for retirement.
Has completed the compulsory COMPRO exam.
questions.explanation: An increment is withheld or deferred if the officer is on interdiction/suspension or has a disciplinary action pending Reference: Emoluments and Discipline.

questions.question: The deferment period for an officer's increment must be fixed and must not be less than three months nor more than:
options: Four months.
Six months.
Nine months.
One year.
questions.explanation: The deferment period must not be less than three months nor more than six months Reference: Deferred Increment.

questions.question: Which officer holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment, requiring assessment of service improvement and conduct
options: Federal Civil Service Commission.
Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.
Accountant-General of the Federation.
The officer’s direct supervisor.
questions.explanation: The Permanent Secretary/Head of Extra-Ministerial Office holds the authority to decide on restoring a deferred increment Reference: Increment Restoration.

subcategories.name: Circulars: Leave, Welfare & Allowances
subcategories.description: Official circular updates on leave, welfare, and allowances.

questions.question: Which Establishment Circular formally approved **Paternity Leave** for male officers in the Nigerian Public Service
options: 2011 Circular on Leave Administration.
2014 Circular on Leave Computation and Paternity Leave.
2017 Circular on Civil Service Reforms.
2013 Circular on Family Welfare.
questions.explanation: The 2014 OHCSF Circular on 'Computation of Leave Based on Working Days and Approval of Paternity Leave' formally introduced paternity leave for male officers Reference: Leave and Welfare.

questions.question: Under the 2014 Circular, computation of annual leave days is based on which calendar basis
options: Calendar days (365 days).
Working days, excluding weekends and public holidays.
Public holidays only.
Weekends only.
questions.explanation: Leave computation was adjusted to working days, excluding weekends and public holidays, for fairness and clarity Reference: Leave Administration.

questions.question: The 2015 Establishment Circular directed that all **MDAs** must approve and submit their annual leave rosters by which quarter of the year
options: First quarter.
Second quarter.
Third quarter.
Fourth quarter.
questions.explanation: All MDAs were directed to submit approved leave rosters by the first quarter to enable effective planning and control of staff absences Reference: Leave Administration.

questions.question: The 2011 Circular on staff welfare mandated the establishment of which committee in **MDAs** to oversee staff wellbeing
options: Procurement Committee.
Welfare Committee.
Budget Committee.
Promotion Committee.
questions.explanation: The 2011 Circular mandated the creation of Welfare Committees to oversee staff wellbeing and morale within MDAs Reference: Staff Welfare.

questions.question: The 2013 Circular on Staff Loans directed that loan applications must be supported by what document for verification
options: Letter of Recommendation.
Last Pay Slip.
Certificate of Service.
Leave Form.
questions.explanation: The Circular required that staff loan applications be accompanied by the applicant's most recent pay slip for verification Reference: Staff Welfare and Loans.

questions.question: The 2012 Circular on Duty Tour Allowance (DTA) revised rates primarily based on what determining factor
options: Length of service.
Grade level.
Zonal location.
Years in office.
questions.explanation: The revised duty tour allowance rates were based on officers' grade levels to ensure equity and reflect inflation trends Reference: Duty Tour Allowances.

questions.question: Which specific body in the Federal Public Service reviews allowances and makes recommendations based on circulars initiated by the **OHCSF**'
options: The Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC).
The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC).
The Budget Office of the Federation.
The Office of the Accountant-General.
questions.explanation: The National Salaries, Incomes and Wages Commission (NSIWC) reviews allowances in the Federal Public Service Reference: Allowance Review.

questions.question: The maximum sick leave period before a Medical Board examination is mandatory, according to the **PSR**:
options: 30 days.
90 days (three months).
Six months.
Twelve months.
questions.explanation: If an officer is still not fit for duty after three months (90 days) sick leave, examination by a Medical Board shall be required Reference: Medical Welfare.

questions.question: Which category of leave practice is explicitly listed in the **PSR** (and consequently eliminated in operational circulars) as abolished
options: Annual Leave.
Deferred Leave.
Sick Leave.
Maternity Leave.
questions.explanation: Deferred Leave is listed as one of the types of leave that is abolished Reference: Leave Administration.

questions.question: If an officer receives more leave during the leave year than they are eligible for, they will be required to refund the excess salary based on the number of:
options: Calendar days.
Working days’ leave enjoyed in excess.
Months.
Weeks.
questions.explanation: The officer shall be required to refund salary calculated at the rate it was paid for the number of working days’ leave enjoyed in excess Reference: Leave Forfeiture.

questions.question: Officers who are going on religious pilgrimages, other than Officials assigned to cover such activities, should utilize which leave type
options: Special Leave of Absence.
Annual leave.
Sick leave.
Study leave.
questions.explanation: Officers going on religious pilgrimages should use part of their annual leave for such purposes Reference: Leave Utilization.

questions.question: An officer who is dismissed from the service shall forfeit all claims to retiring benefits, leave, or transport grant, subject to the provisions of the:
options: Fiscal Responsibility Act.
Pension Reform Act, 2014 (as amended).
Public Procurement Act.
Freedom of Information Act.
questions.explanation: Dismissal results in forfeiture of benefits, subject to the provisions of the Pension Reform Act, 2014 (as amended).

questions.question: The **PSR** mandates that all allowances, such as House Master/Mistress allowance or Science Teaching Allowance, shall be paid at the rates specified in which official document
options: The Appropriation Act.
The Scheme of Service.
The Extant Circular.
The Budget Call Circular.
questions.explanation: Allowances are paid at the rates specified in the Extant Circular Reference: Allowances.

questions.question: What is the maximum duration of study leave with pay that may be granted to an Officer
options: Six months.
Two years.
Three years.
Four years.
questions.explanation: The duration of study leave with pay shall not exceed two years Reference: Study Leave.

questions.question: The length of vacation leave granted to an Officer on invalidation (medically unfit to continue service) shall be two months and will commence:
options: Six months before the official retirement date.
On the day the Medical Board declares him unfit.
On the first day of the following calendar year.
Only upon Ministerial approval.
questions.explanation: The two months leave granted upon invalidation commences on the day the Medical Board declares the Officer permanently unfit for service Reference: Medical Invalidation.

questions.question: If an officer on vacation leave is recalled to duty by the Permanent Secretary, the officer is entitled to resume the unexpired portion of his leave when
options: Operationally, immediately upon return to the office under normal controls.
On the day he ceases to hold a substantive post or act in another post in the same station.
In practice, after three months of continuous service in authorized administrative workflow.
Only at the discretion of the FCSC.
questions.explanation: The unexpired portion of his leave may be resumed on the day he ceases to hold a substantive post, or act in another post in the same station.

subcategories.name: Circulars: Personnel, Performance & Reforms
subcategories.description: Official circular updates on personnel and reform directives.

questions.question: According to the 2015 Establishment Circular and **PSR** **Rule 040102**, which platform was mandated for salary and personnel management across all **MDAs**'
options: GIFMIS.
IPPIS.
REMITA.
HRMIS.
questions.explanation: The 2015 OHCSF Circular made the Integrated Personnel and Payroll Information System (IPPIS) mandatory for all MDAs to ensure payroll integrity Reference: Personnel Management.

questions.question: All newly employed Officers must be placed on the **IPPIS** platform within a maximum period of:
options: Seven days.
One month.
Two months of assumption of duty.
Six months.
questions.explanation: All Officers shall be placed on the IPPIS platform within two months of assumption of duty (Rule 040102).

questions.question: The 2016 Circular on Biometric Capture mandated which activity for all public officers
options: Mandatory annual declaration of assets.
Completion of biometric registration for identity verification.
Attendance of mandatory ICT training.
Submission of online payslips.
questions.explanation: The 2016 OHCSF Circular on biometric integration mandated all public officers to complete biometric registration to ensure identity verification Reference: HR Modernization.

questions.question: The 2016 Circular on Performance Management introduced which modern HR evaluation tool to replace the Annual Performance Evaluation Report (APER)
options: Competency Framework.
Performance Management System (PMS).
Key Result Area Template.
Staff Nominal Roll.
questions.explanation: The 2016 OHCSF Circular launched the Performance Management System (PMS) to replace the APER and align staff goals with organizational objectives Reference: Performance Management.

questions.question: Which Establishment Circular reinforced **SERVICOM principles** to promote efficiency and citizen-focused service
options: 2011 Circular on Service Delivery.
2014 Circular on Payroll Management.
2016 Circular on Biometric Capture.
2017 Circular on Tenure Review.
questions.explanation: The 2011 Circular on Service Delivery reinforced SERVICOM principles to promote efficiency and citizen-focused service Reference: Service Delivery and Reforms.

questions.question: Who is primarily responsible for cascading the Performance Management System (PMS) framework throughout their respective **MDAs** for full implementation
options: The Head of the Civil Service.
Permanent Secretaries.
Directors of HR.
Supervising Ministers.
questions.explanation: Permanent Secretaries were tasked with cascading the PMS framework throughout their MDAs for full implementation Reference: PMS Implementation.

questions.question: The **PSR** incorporated provisions for **virtual meetings** primarily to reflect what modern necessity
options: Increase political transparency.
Enable remote work continuity during pandemics/emergencies.
Mandate staff travel reduction.
Eliminate physical documents.
questions.explanation: Virtual meetings were introduced to enable remote work continuity during pandemics/emergencies, supporting uninterrupted government business Reference: E-Governance.

questions.question: Who issues Treasury Circulars that provide detailed instructions on financial procedures and implementation, complementing the **PSR** and **FR**'
options: Auditor-General of the Federation.
Minister of Finance.
Accountant-General of the Federation.
Director-General, Budget Office.
questions.explanation: The Accountant-General of the Federation issues Treasury Circulars Reference: Financial Administration.

questions.question: The purpose of the three months **pre-retirement leave** required of officers who give notice of retirement is primarily for:
options: To allow them to apply for transfer.
To attend workshops and prepare documentation for retirement benefits.
To pay back outstanding loans.
To collect their last salary.
questions.explanation: The officer attends workshops and prepares documentation during the three months pre-retirement leave Reference: Retirement Procedures.

questions.question: The implementation of the Reward and Recognition Scheme (R&RS) is intended to encourage excellence, merit, and to ensure high levels of staff:
options: Political alignment.
Motivation.
Financial extravagance.
Stagnation.
questions.explanation: The implementation of the R&RS System encourages excellence, merit, and ensures high levels of staff motivation Reference: Reward and Recognition.

questions.question: The Public Service Awards Ceremony, mandated under the R&RS, shall be held how often to recognize service-wide awardees
options: Monthly.
Quarterly.
Annually.
Every five years.
questions.explanation: The Public Service Awards Ceremony shall be held annually Reference: Reward and Recognition.

questions.question: Who is statutorily designated as the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government, coordinating fiscal circulars and policy
options: Accountant-General.
Auditor-General.
Minister of Finance.
Budget Office Director.
questions.explanation: The Minister of Finance is the Chief Financial Adviser to the Federal Government Reference: Financial Management.

questions.question: The compulsory Confirmation/Promotion Examination (COMPRO) must be passed by eligible officers within how many years from the date of taking up their appointments
options: One year.
Two years.
Three years.
Four years.
questions.explanation: Officers must pass the confirmation examination within two years from the date of taking up their appointments Reference: Confirmation Examination.

questions.question: If an officer on **GL 14** meets all criteria, the minimum number of years required on the grade level before being considered for promotion to **GL 15** is:
options: Two years.
Three years.
Four years.
Five years.
questions.explanation: An officer on GL 14 can be considered for promotion after spending a minimum of 3 years on the grade (Rule 020802(c)).
